title: Biscathorpe Walk Route

images.title: Tim Heaton / View across site of medieval village of Biscathorpe
images.caption: View across site of medieval village of Biscathorpe. Very little to see in terms of the old village. But a nice view across the River Bain towards the church of St Helen

images.title: David Wright / Near Biscathorpe
images.caption: Near Biscathorpe. Photo taken from the footbridge over the River Bain leading to the site of the deserted medieval village and looking towards the Old Vicarage.

images.title: David Wright / Ford near Biscathorpe
images.caption: Ford near Biscathorpe. There are two small fords on the road between Gayton-le-Wold and Biscathorpe. This is the more northerly

images.title: David Wright / Biscathorpe - Disused Workings
images.caption: Disused Workings. The site was apparently known as Top Pit. It has been used in the past as a landfill site for the disposal of solid inert waste, hence the grassy mounds. I do not know what was being extracted when the workings were active.

images.title: David Wright / The Viking Way
images.caption: Looking along the Viking Way which is heading for the deserted medieval village of East Wykeham. Photo taken from Grim's Mound which stands just above the 120m contour.

images.title: Ian Paterson / Wykeham Hall Approach
images.caption: Wykeham Hall Approach. Taken from East Wykeham Medieval Village, this view takes in a glimpse of the access road and small lake adjoining Wykeham Hall just to the right of the large oak tree.

images.title: Lake near Biscathorpe by Jonathan Thacker, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lake south of Biscathorpe

images.title: Ian Paterson / "New" House from East Wykeham Medieval Village
images.caption: "New" House from East Wykeham Medieval Village. The ridges in the foreground mark some of the only remaining features of this Medieval Village.

description: This Lincolnshire Wolds walk takes you from the medieval village at Biscathorpe to another medieval site at nearby Wykeham. It's an attractive area with lovely views of the River Bain valley and some interesting historical sites to investigate. The walk starts at Biscathorpe Park next to the site of the ancient settlement. Here you can pick up the Viking Way and follow the waymarked trail north towards on Burgh on Bain and Grimblethorpe. The route then turns west, crossing the River Bain, before coming to Wykeham with its hall, pond and ancient village. The ruins of the 14th century church are still visible. Wykeham Hall survived the abandonment of the village, and still stands. The village is located just a few miles west of Louth where you can enjoy an easy waterside walk along the Louth Canal .
